author: HCAndersen
text: A WHIPPING TOP and a little ball lay together in a box, among other toys, and the top said to the ball, "Shall we be married, as we live in the same box?"

author: HCAndersen
text: But the ball, which wore a dress of morocco leather, and thought as much of herself as any other young lady, would not even condescend to reply.

author: HCAndersen
text: The next day came the little boy to whom the playthings belonged, and he painted the top red and yellow, and drove a brass-headed nail into the middle, so that while the top was spinning round it looked splendid.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Look at me," said the top to the ball.

author: HCAndersen
text: "What do you say now?

author: HCAndersen
text: Shall we be engaged to each other?

author: HCAndersen
text: We should suit so well; you spring, and I dance.

author: HCAndersen
text: No one could be happier than we should be."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Indeed! do you think so?

author: HCAndersen
text: Perhaps you do not know that my father and mother were morocco slippers, and that I have a Spanish cork in my body."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes; but I am made of mahogany," said the top.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The major himself turned me.

author: HCAndersen
text: He has a turning lathe of his own, and it is a great amusement to him."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Can I believe it?" asked the ball.

author: HCAndersen
text: "May I never be whipped again," said the top, "if I am not telling you the truth."

author: HCAndersen
text: "You certainly know how to speak for yourself very well," said the ball; "but I cannot accept your proposal.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am almost engaged to a swallow.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every time I fly up in the air, he puts his head out of the nest, and says, 'Will you?' and I have said, 'Yes,' to myself silently, and that is as good as being half engaged; but I will promise never to forget you."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Much good that will be to me," said the top; and they spoke to each other no more.

author: HCAndersen
text: Next day the ball was taken out by the boy.

author: HCAndersen
text: The top saw it flying high in the air, like a bird, till it would go quite out of sight.

author: HCAndersen
text: Each time it came back, as it touched the earth, it gave a higher leap than before, either because it longed to fly upwards, or from having a Spanish cork in its body.

author: HCAndersen
text: But the ninth time it rose in the air, it remained away, and did not return.

author: HCAndersen
text: The boy searched everywhere for it, but he searched in vain, for it could not be found; it was gone.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I know very well where she is," sighed the top; "she is in the swallow's nest, and has married the swallow."

author: HCAndersen
text: The more the top thought of this, the more he longed for the ball.

author: HCAndersen
text: His love increased the more, just because he could not get her; and that she should have been won by another, was the worst of all.

author: HCAndersen
text: The top still twirled about and hummed, but he continued to think of the ball; and the more he thought of her, the more beautiful she seemed to his fancy.

author: HCAndersen
text: Thus several years passed by, and his love became quite old.

author: HCAndersen
text: The top, also, was no longer young; but there came a day when he looked handsomer than ever; for he was gilded all over.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was now a golden top, and whirled and danced about till he hummed quite loud, and was something worth looking at; but one day he leaped too high, and then he, also, was gone.

author: HCAndersen
text: They searched everywhere, even in the cellar, but he was nowhere to be found.

author: HCAndersen
text: Where could he be?

author: HCAndersen
text: He had jumped into the dust-bin, where all sorts of rubbish were lying: cabbage-stalks, dust, and rain-droppings that had fallen down from the gutter under the roof.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now I am in a nice place," said he; "my gilding will soon be washed off here.

author: HCAndersen
text: Oh dear, what a set of rabble I have got amongst!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And then he glanced at a curious round thing like an old apple, which lay near a long, leafless cabbage-stalk.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was, however, not an apple, but an old ball, which had lain for years in the gutter, and was soaked through with water.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Thank goodness, here comes one of my own class, with whom I can talk," said the ball, examining the gilded top.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I am made of morocco," she said.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I was sewn together by a young lady, and I have a Spanish cork in my body; but no one would think it, to look at me now.

author: HCAndersen
text: I was once engaged to a swallow; but I fell in here from the gutter under the roof, and I have lain here more than five years, and have been thoroughly drenched.

author: HCAndersen
text: Believe me, it is a long time for a young maiden."

author: HCAndersen
text: The top said nothing, but he thought of his old love; and the more she said, the more clear it became to him that this was the same ball.

author: HCAndersen
text: The servant then came to clean out the dust-bin.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah," she exclaimed, "here is a gilt top."

author: HCAndersen
text: So the top was brought again to notice and honor, but nothing more was heard of the little ball.

author: HCAndersen
text: He spoke not a word about his old love; for that soon died away.

author: HCAndersen
text: When the beloved object has lain for five years in a gutter, and has been drenched through, no one cares to know her again on meeting her in a dust-bin.
